metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
key_issues: Here are the key legal issues extracted from the document:
• Cancellation of trademark registration under Sections 57 and 125 of the Trademarks Act, 1999.
• Infringement of petitioner's registered trademark ALPHA for real estate services in Class 36.
• Likelihood of confusion between impugned mark and petitioner's trademark due to similar color scheme and prominent display of word "ALPHA".

• Malafide intentions of respondent no.1 company in adopting a trade name that is too similar to the petitioner's trademark, considering the incorporation of the company by ex-employees before their resignation.
• Passing off: Whether respondent no.1 has passed off its business as that of the petitioner by using a similar trademark and misrepresenting its connection with the petitioner.
• Dilution of goodwill and reputation of the petitioner's mark due to the impugned registration.
• Priority of use and reputation in respect of the mark ALPHA.
• Validity of respondent no.1's trademark registration under the Trademarks Act, 1999.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Comprehensive Summary of Case: Alpha Corp Development Private Limited v. Alpha Integrated Management Services Pvt. Ltd.**

**Background:**

Alpha Corp Development Private Limited (Petitioner) is engaged in the business of real estate development and facility management services since 2003. The company has successfully delivered several projects under the mark "ALPHA" and acquired significant goodwill and reputation.

In 2015, the ex-employees of Petitioner's subsidiary company incorporated Alpha Integrated Management Services Pvt. Ltd. (Respondent No.1), which later filed a trademark application for the mark ("impugned mark") in respect of similar services as that of Petitioner.

**Legal Issues:**

The case revolves around Section 57 and 125 of the Trademarks Act, 1999, which deals with rectification of trademarks. The Petitioner sought the cancellation/removal of the impugned mark, alleging:

1. **Prior Rights:** The Petitioner claimed prior rights in the name "ALPHA" through its registrations (1483826 and 1483827) on September 1, 2006.
2. **Malafides:** The Respondent No.1 was allegedly incorporated by ex-employees of the Petitioner's subsidiary company, which exhibited malafide intentions.
3. **Similarity:** The impugned mark resembles the Petitioner's marks in terms of color scheme, font, and overall appearance.

**Arguments:**

Petitioner's arguments:

*   Prior rights in the name "ALPHA" existed before Respondent No.1 applied for registration of the impugned mark.
*   Malafides on part of Respondent No.1 are evident from its incorporation by ex-employees of Petitioner's subsidiary company.
*   Similarity between the impugned mark and Petitioner's marks raises trademark infringement concerns.

Respondent No.1 did not attend the hearing, making their arguments unavailable.

**Court Findings:**

The court held that:

1.  **Prior Rights:** The court acknowledged the Petitioner's prior rights in the name "ALPHA," citing its earlier registrations.
2.  **Malafides:** The court inferred malafide intentions on part of Respondent No.1 from their suspicious circumstances and Respondent No.1's failure to appear before the court.
3.  **Similarity:** The court noted resemblance between the impugned mark and Petitioner's marks, specifically in terms of color scheme and overall appearance.

**Decision:**

Considering the findings above, the Court ordered:

*   Cancellation/removal of registration number 3187803 for the impugned mark.
*   A warning to Respondent No.1 that further malafide activities would be dealt with strictly.

In conclusion, this case involved a dispute over trademark registration and infringement claims. The court thoroughly examined prior rights, malafides, and similarity between marks before rendering its decision.
metadata.full_text:
--- PAGE 1 ---
2023:DHC:1982 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 393/2022                                              Page 1 of 7 
 
* 
IN  THE  HIGH  COURT  OF  DELHI  AT  NEW  DELHI 
% 
 
 
 
 
 
Date of Decision : 17th March, 2023 
 
+  
 
 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 393/2022 
 
 
ALPHA CORP DEVELOPMENT PRIVATE  
LIMITED  
 
 
 
 
 
..... Petitioner 
Through: 
Mr. Sagar Chandra, Ms.Srijan Uppal, 
Mr. Abhishek Bhati and Ms.Anisha 
Roy, Advocates. 
 
 
 
 
versus 
 
 
ALPHA INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT  
SERVICES PVT. LTD. AND ANR.  
 
..... Respondents 
 
 
 
 
Through: 
None. 
 
CORAM: 
 
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMIT BANSAL 
AMIT BANSAL, J. (Oral) 
1. 
The present rectification petition has been filed on behalf of the 
petitioner seeking cancellation/removal of the trademark bearing registration 
number 3187803 and registered in the name of respondent no.1 in respect of 
real estate services in Class 36 under Sections 57 and 125 of the Trademarks 
Act, 1999 (hereinafter ‘Act’).  
Case set up by the petitioner 
2. 
The case set up by the petitioner in the petition is as follows:  
2.1 
The petitioner, Alpha Corp Development Private Limited, is engaged 
in the business of real estate development including development of 
malls, hotels, townships, multiplexes and complexes and provides 
facility management services such as maintenance, building 
automation, security services among others, since 2003. 
2.2 
The petitioner is the registered proprietor of the mark ALPHA 
through its predecessor-in-interest, M/s Grandeur Estates Private 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:20.03.2023 18:55:18
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
2023:DHC:1982 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 393/2022                                              Page 2 of 7 
 
Limited, bearing registration no. 1483826 and 1483827 in Classes 36 
and 37 of the Act. Several other registrations have also been obtained 
by the petitioner in respect of the mark ALPHA and its formative 
marks. The earliest registration was granted on 1st September, 2006.  
2.3 
The petitioner has successfully delivered several real estate projects 
under the mark ALPHA, such as Alpha International City, Karnal 
(Haryana), 
Alpha 
International 
City, 
Fatehabad 
(Haryana), 
GurgaonOne-84 among others.  
2.4 
The petitioner has also won several real estate awards and accolades 
over the years. Due to long and extensive use of the mark ALPHA, 
the petitioner has acquired vast goodwill and reputation. The annual 
sales of the petitioner in the year 2018 amounted to Rs. 988,145,000/- 
and the petitioner has also incurred expenditure of Rs.6,241,000/- 
towards advertisement and promotions in the said year.  
2.5 
The respondent no.1 has obtained registration of the mark 
 
(hereinafter ‘impugned mark’ ) in respect of similar services as that of 
the petitioner, in the name of the respondent no.1 under application 
no. 3187803 in Class 36 of the Act. The letter 'A' and the word 
ALPHA in the impugned mark are written in black colour, which 
shows the intention of the respondent no. 1 to give prominence to the 
mark ALPHA in the impugned mark. The colour scheme adopted by 
the respondent no.1 for the impugned mark is also similar to that of 
the petitioner’s ALPHA marks.  
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:20.03.2023 18:55:18
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
2023:DHC:1982 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 393/2022                                              Page 3 of 7 
 
2.6 
The malafides of the respondent no.l is evident from the fact that the 
respondent no.l company was incorporated by the ex-employees of 
the petitioner and its subsidiary company, Alpha G: Corp 
Management Services Pvt. Ltd., on 23rd July, 2015, which is prior to 
the date of resignation of the said employees. The said employees had 
complete access to the records and data of the petitioner and its 
subsidiary company. 
2.7 
Public caution notices were published by the petitioner's subsidiary 
company in various newspapers when it came to know that its ex-
employees had incorporated a new company with confusingly similar 
name for providing identical services of facility management. 
Thereafter, the respondent no.1 filed a defamation complaint before 
Tis Hazari Courts, New Delhi. Against the summoning order dated 
14th May, 2016 passed in the aforementioned defamation complaint, 
the petitioner filed a CRL.M.C. No.297/2017 before this Court, which 
is pending adjudication.  
2.8 
The petitioner filed an application being SRN G43969063 dated 6th 
February, 2017 before Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA) under 
Section 16 of the Companies Act, 2013 seeking a direction to the 
respondent no. 1 to rectify its deceptively similar/identical trade 
name. The Regional Director, MCA held that the trade name of the 
respondent no.1 closely resembles the name of the subsidiary 
company of the petitioner and directed them to change the name of 
their company vide order dated 1st August, 2017.  
2.9 
The impugned mark was published in the Trade Mark Journal on 18th 
September, 2017. However, the respondent no. 1 concealed the 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:20.03.2023 18:55:18
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
2023:DHC:1982 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 393/2022                                              Page 4 of 7 
 
factum of passing of the aforementioned order by the Regional 
Director regarding change of name of the respondent no.1 company. 
2.10 The respondent no.l has challenged the aforesaid order of the 
Regional Director by filing a Writ Petition Civil No. 24380/2017 
before High Court of Punjab and Haryana, which is presently pending 
adjudication. However, the High Court of Punjab and Haryana vide 
order dated 30th October, 2017 has stayed the operation of the order 
dated 1st August, 2017 passed by the Regional Director. 
2.11 The impugned mark has been adopted by the respondent no. 1 with 
the sole intention of riding on the goodwill of the petitioner and to 
create confusion in the minds of the public and trade channel. 
2.12 Accordingly, the present rectification has been filed by the petitioner.  
Proceedings in the petition 
3. 
 Notice in the present petition was issued by the Intellectual Property 
Appellate Board (IPAB) on 1st November, 2018. However, the respondent 
no.1 failed to appear before IPAB despite service. The respondent no.1 was 
proceeded against ex parte on 21st January, 2020. Thereafter, the present 
rectification got transferred to this Court after coming into effect of 
Tribunals Reforms Act, 2022 and the Court notice was issued to the 
respondent no.1 by this Court on 28th March, 2022. However, none appeared 
on behalf of the respondent no.1 despite service. 
4. 
It was noted in the order dated 23rd January, 2023 that the respondent 
no.1 has changed its corporate name from ‘Alpha Integrated Management 
Service Private Limited to ‘Abante Integrated Management Services Private 
Limited’. Further, on 15th February, 2023, the counsel for the petitioner 
handed over fresh trademark registrations granted in favour of the 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:20.03.2023 18:55:18
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
2023:DHC:1982 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 393/2022                                              Page 5 of 7 
 
respondent no.1 in respect of the marks 
(logo)  , 
(device) 
and ‘ABANTE’ (word). The court notice was also issued to the respondent 
no.1 including through attorney, who applied for the aforesaid registrations 
on his behalf on the said date. Court notice was duly served on the 
respondent no.1’s attorney. Despite service, none has appeared on behalf of 
the respondent no.1. Nor any reply/counter-statement has been filed on 
behalf of the respondent no.1. It is indicative of the fact that the respondent 
no.1 is not interested in pursuing the present petition, as it has already 
changed its trademark and its corporate name.  
Analysis and Findings 
5. 
 I have heard the counsels for the parties and perused the record of the 
case.  
6. 
 In order to determine whether the trademark of the respondent no.1 is 
identical to the trademark of the petitioner, it would be apposite to refer to 
the two competing trademarks, as set out below:  
Respondent no.1’s Trademark 
Petitioner’s Trademarks 
 
  ALPHA 
  
 
 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:20.03.2023 18:55:18
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
2023:DHC:1982 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 393/2022                                              Page 6 of 7 
 
7. 
It is pertinent to note that the prominent and essential feature of the 
impugned mark is ‘ALPHA’, which is identical and deceptively similar to 
the petitioner's mark ‘ALPHA’ and its other formative marks in respect of 
similar services. Therefore, the registration of the impugned mark is in 
contravention of Section 11(1) of the Act.  
8. 
The respondent no. 1 was well aware of the petitioner's mark ALPHA 
since respondent no. 1 was incorporated by ex-employees of the petitioner. 
There can be no plausible reason for the respondent no. 1 to have chosen an 
identical and a deceptively similar mark as that of the petitioner's mark for 
identical goods. Clearly, the adoption of the mark by the respondent no.1 is 
dishonest and therefore, the respondent no.1 is not entitled to the benefit of 
Section 12 of the Act.  
9. 
From the facts detailed above, it is clear that the petitioner is the 
proprietor of the impugned mark. The respondent no.1 cannot claim to be 
the proprietor of the impugned trademark as there is nothing to show as to 
how the impugned trademark has been adopted by the respondent no.1. 
Therefore, the application for registration of the impugned trademark is in 
contravention of Section 18(1) of the Act. Further, the respondent no.1 is 
also not entitled to the benefit of Section 11(4) of the Act as the petitioner 
has not consented to the use of the impugned mark by the respondent no.1. 
10. 
The grant of registration of the impugned trademark by the respondent 
no.2 is against the principles of Section 11(3)(a) of the Act, as there is no 
dispute that the petitioner is the prior user of the impugned trademark since 
2003 in India. Due to such a long, continuous and extensive use, the 
impugned mark is solely associated with the petitioner. Therefore, the 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:20.03.2023 18:55:18
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
2023:DHC:1982 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 393/2022                                              Page 7 of 7 
 
registration of the impugned trademark should have been refused by the 
respondent no.2. 
11. 
In view of the discussion above, it is clear that the impugned 
trademark has been adopted by the respondent no.1 dishonestly to trade 
upon the established goodwill and reputation of the petitioner and to project 
itself to be associated with the petitioner. The nature of the impugned 
trademark is such that it will deceive the public and create confusion as 
regards the source of the goods manufactured and sold under the impugned 
trademark.  
12. 
Accordingly, the present petition is allowed and the impugned 
trademark registered under trademark application no. 3187803 in the name 
of the respondent no.1 in Class 36 is removed from the Register of Trade 
Marks.  
13. 
 A copy of the order be sent to the respondents through e-mail. The 
Registry is directed to supply a copy of the present order to the Trademark 
Registry, at e-mail - llc-ipo@gov.in for compliance.  
 
 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J 
MARCH 17, 2023 
sr 
 
 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:20.03.2023 18:55:18
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
**Case Details**

Source: ALPHA vs ALPHA.pdf (PDF file)

**Case Overview**

A rectification petition was filed by Alpha Corp Development Private Limited (petitioner) against Alpha Integrated Management Services PVT. LTD. and ANR. (respondents) in the High Court of Delhi (2023:DHC:1982) on March 17, 2023.

**Parties Involved**

* Petitioner: Alpha Corp Development Private Limited
	+ Represented by Mr. Sagar Chandra, Ms.Srijan Uppal, Mr. Abhishek Bhati, and Ms.Anisha Roy
* Respondents:
	+ Alpha Integrated Management Services PVT. LTD.
	+ ANR.

**Case Set Up**

The petitioner sought the cancellation/removal of trademark registration number 3187803 in respect of real estate services in Class 36 under Sections 57 and 125 of the Trademarks Act, 1999.

**Facts and Arguments**

* Petitioner is a registered proprietor of the mark ALPHA (registration no. 1483826 and 1483827) since 2003.
* The petitioner has multiple other registrations for the mark ALPHA and its formative marks since September 1, 2006.
* Respondent No.1 obtained registration of the impugned mark in Class 36 on the same services as the petitioner.

**Decisions and Amounts**

* The annual sales of the petitioner in 2018 were Rs. 988,145,000/-, with a promotion expenditure of Rs. 6,241,000/-.
* No decision on the case was mentioned in this section.

nodes.title: Page 2
nodes.summary:
Based on page 2 of PDF: 4. Alpha vs Alpha.pdf, here's a summary:

The petitioner, ALPHA CORP DEVELOPMENT PRIVATE LIMITED (Alpha Corp), has been using the mark "ALPHA" since 2006, with various registrations in Classes 36 and 37 of the Act. They have successfully completed several real estate projects, including Alpha International City in Karnal and GurgaonOne-84. The petitioner has won numerous awards and accumulated goodwill over time.

In the year 2018, their annual sales were Rs. 988,145,000/-. They also spent Rs. 6,241,000/- on advertising and promotions. Respondent No.1, ALPHA INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT SERVICES PVT. LTD., obtained a registration for the mark "" in Class 36 of the Act, with a similar color scheme to Alpha Corp's marks.

Key dates: September 1, 2006 (earliest registration), March 17, 2023 (date of decision).
Legal facts:

* Registration no.:1483826 and 1483827
* Application No.: 3187803

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
**C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 393/2022**

This is a High Court of Delhi case where **Alpha Corp Development Private Limited (Petitioner)** filed a complaint against **Alpha Integrated Management Services PVT. LTD. and ANR. (Respondent no.1)**.

**Background and Facts:**

* The respondent was incorporated in 2015 by ex-employees of the petitioner's subsidiary company, with access to its records and data.
* Public caution notices were published by the subordinate companies when they learned about the new company's similar name for facility management services.
* The respondent filed a defamation complaint in 2016 against the summoning order, which is pending before this Court.

**Key Events:**

1. On February 6, 2017, the petitioner filed an application under Section 16 of the Companies Act, 2013 to direct the respondent no.1 to rectify its deceptively similar/identical trade name.
2. The Regional Director, MCA held that the trade name closely resembles the subsidiary company's name and directed the respondent to change it on August 1, 2017.
3. The impugned mark was published in the Trade Mark Journal on September 18, 2017.

**Reference:**
PDF Source: **Alpha vs Alpha.pdf**, Context: 2023:DHC:1982 (Source not confirmed)

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 3:

**PDF Source:** Alpha vs Alpha.pdf (2023:DHC:1982)

**Legal Facts and Proceedings:**

* The respondent company was incorporated by ex-employees of the petitioner on July 23, 2015.
* Public caution notices were published by the petitioner's subsidiary company to warn against a new company with a similar name.
* A defamation complaint was filed by the respondent, leading to a CRL.M.C. case (No.297/2017) in Delhi High Court.
* The petitioner applied to the Ministry of Corporate Affairs under Section 16 of the Companies Act, 2013, seeking directions to change the respondent's deceptively similar trade name.

**Directions and Orders:**

* Regional Director, MCA ordered the respondent to change their company's trade name due to resemblance with the petitioner's subsidiary company's name on August 1, 2017.
* The impugned mark was published in the Trade Mark Journal on September 18, 2017.

Note: This summary is under 200 words.

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
**Law Case Summary:** Alpha Corp Development Private Limited vs Alpha Integrated Management Services PVT. LTD.

**PDF Source:** 2023:DHC:1982 (Case No.: C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 393/2022)

**Key Facts and Decisions:**

* The Petitioner, Alpha Corp Development Private Limited, applied for a rectification of trademark to cancel the mark adopted by Respondent No.1, Alpha Integrated Management Services PVT. LTD.
* The Respondent No.1 has changed its corporate name from 'Alpha' to 'Abante' and registered trademarks in respect of various marks including 'ABANTE'.
* Notice was issued to the Respondent No.1, who failed to appear despite service.
* The Court found that the prominent feature of the impugned mark is 'ALPHA', which is identical and deceptively similar to the Petitioner's mark 'ALPHA' and its other formative marks.

**Court Decisions:**

* It was decided that the registration of the impugned mark is a contravention of Section 11(1) of the Act.
* The Court found no plausible reason for the Respondent No.1 to have chosen an identical and deceptively similar mark as that of the Petitioner's mark.

**Parties and Dates:**

* Parties involved: Alpha Corp Development Private Limited (Petitioner), Alpha Integrated Management Services PVT. LTD. (Respondent No.1)
* Filing Date of Writ Petition Civil No. 24380/2017 by Respondent No.1: 07 July, 2017
* Date of Decision: 17th March, 2023

**Amounts/Monies:**

* No amounts mentioned in the PDF source.

Note that this summary aims to capture only key aspects and does not encompass all details or analyses in the original document.

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 4 from "Alpha vs Alpha.pdf" (2023:DHC:1982):

**Proceedings in the petition**

* Notice was issued by IPAB on November 1, 2018, but respondent no.1 failed to appear.
* Respondent no.1 was proceeded against ex parte on January 21, 2020.
* The rectification case got transferred to this Court after Tribunals Reforms Act, 2022 came into effect.
* A court notice was issued to respondent no.1 on March 28, 2022, but they failed to appear despite service.

**New developments**

* It was noted that respondent no.1 has changed its corporate name from 'Alpha Integrated Management Service Private Limited' to 'Abante Integrated Management Services Private Limited'.
* On February 15, 2023, the petitioner's counsel handed over fresh trademark registrations granted in favor of the petitioner.

Source: "Alpha vs Alpha.pdf" (2023:DHC:1982)

Service Private Limited to ‘Abante Integrated Management Services Private 
Limited’. Further, on 15th February, 2023, the counsel for the petitioner 
handed over fresh trademark registrations granted in favour of the

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary:
Based on page 6 of the PDF "Alpha vs Alpha.pdf" (Source: 2023:DHC:1982), here is a summary of the key legal facts, proceedings, arguments, decisions, dates, names, and amounts:

**Summary**

The petitioner, Alpha Corp Development Private Limited, challenged the registration of the respondent's trademark, which the court found to be deceptively similar to the petitioner's mark "ALPHA" and its variants. The court held that the respondent had knowingly adopted an identical mark without any plausible reason, indicating dishonesty.

**Legal Findings**

* Contravention of Section 11(1) of the Trademarks Act: registration of impugned mark without consent of the prior user.
* Contravention of Section 18(1): respondent not authorized to use the impugned mark.
* Denial of benefit under Section 12: respondent's adoption of impugned mark was dishonest.
* Grant of registration against principles of Section 11(3)(a): petitioner was prior user since 2003.

**Names and Dates**

* Petitioner: Alpha Corp Development Private Limited
* Respondent No.1: Alpha Integrated Management Services Pvt. Ltd.
* Date: 17th March, 2023
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:1982 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 393/2022                                              Page 6 of 7 
 
7. 
It is pertinent to note that the prominent and essential feature of the 
impugned mark is ‘ALPHA’, which is identical and deceptively similar to 
the petitioner's mark ‘ALPHA’ and its other formative marks in respect of 
similar services. Therefore, the registration of the impugned mark is in 
contravention of Section 11(1) of the Act.  
8. 
The respondent no. 1 was well aware of the petitioner's mark ALPHA 
since respondent no. 1 was incorporated by ex-employees of the petitioner. 
There can be no plausible reason for the respondent no. 1 to have chosen an 
identical and a deceptively similar mark as that of the petitioner's mark for 
identical goods. Clearly, the adoption of the mark by the respondent no.1 is 
dishonest and therefore, the respondent no.1 is not entitled to the benefit of 
Section 12 of the Act.  
9. 
From the facts detailed above, it is clear that the petitioner is the 
proprietor of the impugned mark. The respondent no.1 cannot claim to be 
the proprietor of the impugned trademark as there is nothing to show as to 
how the impugned trademark has been adopted by the respondent no.1. 
Therefore, the application for registration of the impugned trademark is in 
contravention of Section 18(1) of the Act. Further, the respondent no.1 is 
also not entitled to the benefit of Section 11(4) of the Act as the petitioner 
has not consented to the use of the impugned mark by the respondent no.1. 
10. 
The grant of registration of the impugned trademark by the respondent 
no.2 is against the principles of Section 11(3)(a) of the Act, as there is no 
dispute that the petitioner is the prior user of the impugned trademark since 
2003 in India. Due to such a long, continuous and extensive use, the 
impugned mark is solely associated with the petitioner. Therefore, the 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:20.03.2023 18:55:18
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
**Summary of Court Decision**

The document is a court decision from the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi (2023:DHC:1982), specifically **C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 393/2022**, dated March 17, 2023.

**Parties Involved**

* Petitioner: ALPHA CORP DEVELOPMENT PRIVATE LIMITED
* Respondents:
	+ ALPHA INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT SERVICES PVT. LTD. (#1)
	+ Anr. (unknown party #2)

**Facts and Argument**

The petitioner alleged that respondent #1 adopted a trademark dishonestly to trade upon the established goodwill and reputation of the petitioner, creating confusion about the source of goods.

**Court Decision**

* The court held that registration of the impugned trademark should have been refused by the respondent #2.
* The nature of the impugned trademark was deemed deceiving and capable of creating confusion regarding its source.
* **Result:** The present petition is allowed, and the impugned trademark (application no. 3187803 in Class 36) is removed from the Register of Trade Marks.

**Orders and Directions**

* A copy of the order is to be sent to respondents through e-mail.
* The Registry is directed to supply a copy of the present order to the Trademark Registry at **llc-ipo@gov.in** for compliance.

Source: Alpha vs Alpha.pdf (Page 1-7 of 7, Court Decision section)

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 7 from the provided PDF "Alpha vs Alpha.pdf":

This is not an actual page content but an order of the court. I will summarize relevant points:

**Court Order:**

C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 393/2022, dated March 17, 2023

Petitioner: ALPHA CORP DEVELOPMENT PRIVATE LIMITED
Respondent: ALPHA INTEGRATED MANAGEMENT SERVICES PVT. LTD.

**Decision:**

The court allowed the petition and removed the impugned trademark registered under application no. 3187803 in Class 36.

**Rationale:**

The trademark was adopted dishonestly to trade on petitioner's goodwill, reputation, and project an association with the petitioner. The trademark would deceive the public and create confusion regarding its source.

**Order:**

A copy of the order is to be sent to respondents through email, and a copy is to be supplied to the Trademark Registry (llc-ipo@gov.in).

PDF Source: 2023:DHC:1982, Alpha vs Alpha.pdf
nodes.content:
2023:DHC:1982 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 393/2022                                              Page 7 of 7 
 
registration of the impugned trademark should have been refused by the 
respondent no.2. 
11. 
In view of the discussion above, it is clear that the impugned 
trademark has been adopted by the respondent no.1 dishonestly to trade 
upon the established goodwill and reputation of the petitioner and to project 
itself to be associated with the petitioner. The nature of the impugned 
trademark is such that it will deceive the public and create confusion as 
regards the source of the goods manufactured and sold under the impugned 
trademark.  
12. 
Accordingly, the present petition is allowed and the impugned 
trademark registered under trademark application no. 3187803 in the name 
of the respondent no.1 in Class 36 is removed from the Register of Trade 
Marks.  
13. 
 A copy of the order be sent to the respondents through e-mail. The 
Registry is directed to supply a copy of the present order to the Trademark 
Registry, at e-mail - llc-ipo@gov.in for compliance.  
 
 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J 
MARCH 17, 2023
